questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented with hypertension and chest pain. A chest radiograph was taken as shown in the image below. What is the likely cause of hypertension in this patient?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Coarctation of aorta

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and the chest X-ray depicting the figure of 3 sign are suggestive of coarctation of aorta to be the cause of hypertension in this patient.

 

Typical C/F: Brachio-femoral delay – Upper limb pulsations/BP is high; Lower limb pulsation/BP is feeble.

 

Radiological investigation:

 

  • Figure of 3 signs on CXR
  • Inferior rib notching – Roesler's sign 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Essential hypertension: More common in older adults and usually doesn't show specific findings on a chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: Associated with high calcium levels and bone resorption signs, not directly causing visible changes on a chest X-ray linked with hypertension.

 

Option D. Takayasu arteritis: A vasculitis that might show narrowing or dilation of the aorta or its branches, but it typically affects younger women and would likely show different patterns on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta can be identified on a chest X-ray by the "figure of 3" sign, and it should be suspected in young patients presenting with hypertension and signs of upper body hypertension contrasted with lower limb hypotension.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient having a ↓ MCV, ↓ MCH, ↓ transferrin saturation, ↓ serum ferritin, and ↑ Total iron binding capacity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iron deficiency anemia

 

The lab findings indicate a microcytic hypochromic anemia, as shown by decreased Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV) and Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH).

 

The iron profile further confirms iron deficiency anemia: low transferrin saturation, low serum ferritin (indicating depleted iron stores), and increased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC), which reflects the body’s attempt to bind more iron due to deficiency.

 

These findings are classic for iron deficiency anemia, where the primary pathology is a lack of iron needed for hemoglobin synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalassemia: Thalassemia also presents as microcytic hypochromic anemia, but typically shows normal or increased serum ferritin and normal TIBC due to intact iron stores. The pattern of iron studies here does not fit thalassemia.

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: This condition often shows low serum iron, but it is characterized by normal or increased ferritin and decreased TIBC, opposite to the findings in this question.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic anemia: Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by ineffective erythropoiesis and abnormal iron incorporation into hemoglobin, leading to ring sideroblasts in the bone marrow. Serum iron is usually increased, and TIBC is normal or decreased, which does not match the iron deficiency profile described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is identified by microcytic hypochromic anemia with low serum ferritin, low transferrin saturation, and high TIBC, reflecting the body’s response to insufficient iron availability for hemoglobin synthesis.

questions.text: A man with diabetes was on medication and forgot to take his meals before going to the gym. During his workout, he collapsed, and his blood sugar level was found to be 50 mg/dL. Which of the following oral antidiabetic drugs can result in hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glimepiride

 

Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea, a class of drugs that stimulate the pancreas to release more insulin. This increased insulin release can lower blood glucose levels significantly, leading to hypoglycemia, especially if meals are skipped or physical activity is increased. Sulfonylureas are well known for their potential to cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metformin: This drug primarily decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. It rarely causes hypoglycemia when used alone because it does not directly stimulate insulin release.

 

Option C. Acarbose:  An alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that slows carbohydrate absorption in the intestine. It does not cause hypoglycemia when used alone, as it does not affect insulin secretion.

 

Option D. Dapagliflozin:  A sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that promotes glucose excretion in the urine. It has a low risk of causing hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy because it does not increase insulin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Group of drugs that tend to produce hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy:

 

  • Insulin
  • Secretagogues: Sulfonylureas, such as glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy due to their mechanism of increasing insulin release from the pancreas.

questions.text: What type of budding is described by a broad base with a small bud coming off of it, often associated with a figure of 8 appearances? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blastomycosis

 

The term "broad based budding" refers to a type of asexual reproduction in fungi where the bud forms from a broad base rather than a narrow one. This specific budding pattern is characteristic of Blastomycosis, a fungal infection caused by the organism Blastomyces dermatitidis. The appearance of the yeast cells in Blastomycosis is often described as having a broad base with a budding structure that resembles a figure of 8. This visual characteristic is useful in distinguishing Blastomycosis from other fungal infections. The mnemonic "Blasto" helps to remember that "Blasto" implies broad-based budding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryptococcus: This fungus is known for producing yeast cells with a round, encapsulated appearance and does not exhibit broad-based budding. Instead, it forms a distinctive capsule around the yeast cells which is crucial for its identification.

 

Option C. Candidiasis: The causative agent, Candida species, typically shows pseudohyphae and yeast forms, but these do not have the broad-based budding pattern. Candida's budding is more narrow-based compared to that of Blastomycosis.

 

Option D.Histoplasmosis: Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, this fungus forms small yeast cells within macrophages. The budding in Histoplasmosis is more narrow-based and does not resemble the broad-based budding pattern described for Blastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blastomycosis is characterized by broad-based budding with a figure of 8 appearances, where the term "Blasto" helps recall the broad base nature of the budding structure.

choices.text: Motor speech area
Wernicke's area
Auditory area

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Motor speech area

 

Explanation

 

  • Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus
  • Broca area is the motor area for speech. It includes areas 44 and 45. Broca area is present in left hemisphere (dominant hemisphere) of right-handed persons and in the right hemisphere of left-handed persons.
  • It is a special region of premotor cortex situated in inferior frontal gyrus. Area 44 is situated in pars triangularis and 45 in pars opercularis of this gyrus.
  • Broca aphasia is the non-fluent speech problem. It occurs due to lesion in left frontal lobe of cerebral cortex. It is also known as expressive aphasia or anterior aphasia. The affected persons do not complete the sentences because of their inability to construct the sentences. They often talk in short phrases by omitting small words such as ‘and’, ‘is’, ‘for’, etc. They make great efforts even to initiate speech. Persons with Broca aphasia are able to understand spoken or written words.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's area: Incorrect. Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe, not the inferior frontal gyrus. It is responsible for the comprehension of speech and language.

 

Option C. Auditory area: Incorrect. The primary auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe, which is involved in processing auditory information.

 

Option D. Visual area: Incorrect. The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe, which is primarily responsible for processing visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the inferior frontal gyrus is likely to impact Broca's area, leading to deficits in motor speech production known as Broca's aphasia. This condition manifests as difficulty in speech articulation and sentence construction, significantly affecting verbal communication despite preserved comprehension.

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lingual nerve

 

Lingual Nerve: This is the branch of mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It runs close to the submandibular gland and is therefore at risk during submandibular gland surgery.

 

Sensory Distribution: Provides general sensory (pain, temperature, touch) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. (Note: Taste sensation for this region is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, which joins the lingual nerve for a short course.)

 

Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of general sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

 

 

Injury:

 

Because dissection of the submandibular duct from the nerve is required during submandibular gland resection, the lingual nerve is at risk of injury. It is also linked to the submandibular ganglion, which will expose the nerve within the operating field.

 

The symptoms of lingual nerve injury differ depending on whether the lesion is proximal or distal to the point where it is joined by the chorda tympani nerve.

 

  • Proximal injury: There is loss of sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, gingivae, oral mucosa, lower lip, and chin.
  • Distal injury: In addition to features of proximal injury, secretion from the salivary glands below the oral fissure and taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is also lost.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nerve to Mylohyoid: This nerve is a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3). It descends on the medial surface of the mandible in the mylohyoid groove.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in the elevation of the hyoid bone and floor of the mouth during swallowing and speech.

 

Option B. Inferior Alveolar Nerve: It's a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It enters the mandibular foramen and runs through the mandibular canal.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Does not directly supply any muscles.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the mandibular teeth, lower lip, and chin.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option D. Hypoglossal Nerve (12th Cranial Nerve): This cranial nerve exits the skull via the hypoglossal canal and supplies the muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies almost all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except the palatoglossus (which is innervated by the vagus nerve).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Tongue deviation to the side of the lesion due to weakened tongue muscles on that side. If you asked the patient to protrude their tongue, it would point towards the side of the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Defense wounds

 

The image shows multiple wounds on the hand, indicative of defense wounds. These are injuries received by a victim of an attack while trying to defend against the assailant.

 

Defense wounds are typically found on the hands and forearms, showing deep incised or blunt force injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antemortem wound: Wounds inflicted before death, characterized by bleeding, clot formation, and tissue reaction. Defense wounds are a type of antemortem wound, but the specific context here is self-defense.

 

Option C. Postmortem wound: Wounds inflicted after death, characterized by the absence of vital reactions such as bleeding and clotting.

 

Option D. Hesitation cuts: Multiple, small, superficial incised wounds made by a person during a suicide attempt while hesitating to make a final decisive cut.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A district in Madhya Pradesh has CBR 19/1000 LB and CDR is 6/1000 LB. Find the annual growth rate of the district. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1.3%

 

The annual growth rate of a population is calculated using the formula:

 

Annual Growth Rate (AGR) = Crude Birth Rate (CBR) − Crude Death Rate (CDR)

 

In this case:

 

  • CBR = 19 per 1000 live births
  • CDR = 6 per 1000 live births

 

AGR = 19−6 = 13 per 1000

 

To express this as a percentage (which is the standard form for growth rates), you multiply by 0.1:

 

13 × 0.1 = 1.3%

 

Therefore, the annual growth rate for this district is 1.3%.

 

Additional Information –

 

  • Mid-year population is refer to the 1st of July.
  • India is in Stage 3 of Demographic cycle

 

Educational Objective:

 

The annual growth rate of a population is calculated by subtracting the Crude Death Rate (CDR) from the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) and then expressing this difference as a percentage.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with diffuse, severely contaminated perforation peritonitis due to hollow viscus. He underwent laparotomy for it. On day 7 post-op, he developed signs of wound infection and subsequently, the wound showed dehiscence with exposure of underlying tissues as shown below. His vital signs are stable with no evidence of intra-abdominal sepsis. What is the appropriate management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vacuum assisted closure (VAC)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient underwent laparotomy for perforation peritonitis and developed wound infection followed by wound dehiscence on postoperative day 7. Given that:

 

  • The wound is open with exposed underlying tissues.
  • Vital signs are stable.
  • No evidence of intra-abdominal sepsis.

 

This suggests a "burst abdomen" or post-op wound dehiscence, which is best managed using Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC therapy).

 

  • Promotes granulation tissue formation and wound healing.
  • Reduces bacterial load and infection risk.
  • Decreases edema and maintains a moist environment.
  • Prepares the wound for secondary closure or grafting if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suturing of Wound → Incorrect

 

  • Primary closure is not recommended because the wound is infected and dehiscent.
  • Attempting suturing would increase the risk of abscess formation and wound breakdown.

 

Option C. Normal Saline-Soaked Gauze → Partially Correct but Not Ideal

 

  • Saline dressings can be used but do not actively promote wound healing as well as VAC therapy.
  • More suitable for minor dehiscence, not large wounds with exposed tissue.

 

Option D. None of the Above → Incorrect

 

  • The patient requires wound management to prevent secondary infections and facilitate healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy is the best treatment for wound dehiscence after laparotomy, as it promotes granulation tissue formation, reduces infection risk, and optimizes healing.

questions.text: A patient suffered from severe chest pain and expired. Which of the following is the likely age of infarct from the image of the cardiac biopsy shown here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 day

 

The cardiac biopsy image shows significant neutrophilic infiltration, which is a hallmark of early myocardial infarction.

 

 Neutrophilic infiltration in myocardial tissue occurs in two phases: early (within 24 hours) and late (after 24 hours).

 

In the early phase, neutrophils begin to infiltrate the infarcted tissue within the first 24 hours, but their numbers are relatively low. By the second and third days, neutrophil infiltration becomes more pronounced as the body attempts to clear the dead tissue. However, after 72 hours, neutrophils start to be replaced by macrophages. In this question, the presence of numerous neutrophils indicates that the infarct age is close to 1 day, as significant neutrophil accumulation typically peaks around 24 to 48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 3-4 days: By this time, neutrophils are starting to be replaced by macrophages, which are responsible for further cleanup and early stages of healing. Therefore, extensive neutrophilic infiltration would not be seen at this stage.

 

Option C. 7-10 days: At this point, granulation tissue is starting to form, and macrophages predominate the area. Neutrophils would not be the primary cells observed, making this answer incorrect.

 

Option D. 2-3 weeks: By 2-3 weeks, granulation tissue is well established, and the repair process is progressing toward fibrosis. Neutrophils would not be present in large numbers at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brisk neutrophilic infiltration is a characteristic finding in myocardial tissue within the first 24 hours of infarction. The peak of neutrophil presence occurs around the second and third days, followed by the transition to macrophages.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with knee pain following a fall from the stairs. The physical and radiological evaluation revealed injury to the marked structure. Identify the structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tibial tuberosity

 

In this case, the injury is localized to the tibial tuberosity, a prominent bony projection on the anterior aspect of the tibia. The tibial tuberosity serves as the attachment point for the patellar ligament. Injuries to this region, especially in young, active individuals (often seen in adolescents), can be associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease, which is an osteochondritis of the tibial tuberosity. This condition is common in children and adolescents undergoing growth spurts and is characterized by knee pain, swelling, and tenderness at the tibial tuberosity following physical activity or trauma, such as a fall from stairs.

 

The patient in this question, a 10-year-old with knee pain after a fall, shows signs consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medial tubercle: The medial tubercle refers to the medial part of the tibial plateau and is not directly related to the symptoms or the location of the injury in this case.

 

Option C. Gerdy's tubercle: Gerdy's tubercle is the insertion site for the iliotibial band on the lateral side of the tibia. The injury in the image and description does not involve Gerdy's tubercle, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Anterior intercondylar area: This area is located between the condyles of the tibia and is the site of cruciate ligament attachments. However, this is not the structure marked or injured in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibial tuberosity is the site of attachment for the patellar ligament, and injuries to this region, particularly in young individuals, can result in conditions such as Osgood-Schlatter disease, characterized by pain at the site, especially following physical activity or trauma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with persistent nasal congestion, foul-smelling greenish-black nasal crusts, and anosmia. Examination reveals a dry nasal cavity with crust formation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests atrophic rhinitis. 

 

  • The presence of foul-smelling greenish-black discharge (due to Klebsiella ozaenae infection)
  • Anosmia (due to atrophy of nerve elements)
  • Crusting in nasal cavity (due to transformation of normal ciliated columnar epithelium to abnormal stratified squamous epithelium)
  • Female patient (consistent with demographics as atrophic rhinitis commonly affects females)
  • The disease process involves atrophy of nasal mucosa, leading to loss of defense mechanisms (cilia and mucous glands), resulting in secondary infections and crust formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinoscleroma

 

  • While the first stage can mimic atrophic rhinitis, it typically doesn't present with anosmia
  • Characterized by painless nodules giving woody feel ("woody nose" or "hebra nose")
  • Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

 

 

Option C. Hypertrophic rhinitis

 

  • Presents with bilateral inferior turbinate hypertrophy
  • Shows mulberry appearance of turbinates
  • No crusting or anosmia

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis

 

  • Presents with sneezing, itching, and watery discharge
  • IgE-mediated type 1 hypersensitivity reaction
  • No foul smell or crusting
  • Typically shows pale, boggy mucosa

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic Rhinitis (Ozaenae)

questions.text: A man with diabetes was on medication and forgot to take his meals before going to the gym. During his workout, he collapsed, and his blood sugar level was found to be 50 mg/dL. Which of the following oral antidiabetic drugs can result in hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glimepiride

 

Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea, a class of oral antidiabetic drugs known to stimulate insulin release from pancreatic beta cells. This action can lead to a decrease in blood glucose levels, which, if not balanced with adequate food intake, can result in hypoglycemia. The patient's low blood sugar level (50 mg/dL) and the scenario of collapsing during a workout indicate that hypoglycemia occurred, likely due to the effect of glimepiride.

 

[Mnemonic: any drug which ends with “ide” can cause hypoglycemia, except glutides (liraglutide), axenatide]

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that primarily decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. It does not usually cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy because it does not stimulate insulin secretion.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that increases incretin levels, which in turn increases insulin release and decreases glucagon levels. However, it does not generally cause hypoglycemia as monotherapy because its action is glucose-dependent.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that increases insulin sensitivity but does not stimulate insulin release. Thus, it does not typically cause hypoglycemia when used alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sulfonylureas, like glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia, especially when meals are skipped, due to their insulin-stimulating effects.

questions.text: A young boy came to Derma OPD with complaints of severe itching at night. On examination, burrows are seen over intertriginous areas, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits. The disease is transmitted by? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mite

 

The boy's symptoms, including severe nocturnal itching and the presence of burrows in specific body areas (intertriginous regions, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits), are classic signs of scabies. Scabies is a skin condition caused by infestation with the itch mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis. The mite burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, especially at night. The areas affected (often referred to as the circle of Hebra) are characteristic for scabies.

 

 

Circle of Hebra

 

 

Mites

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Louse: Lice infestation, known as pediculosis, typically causes itching but does not present with burrows in the skin or nocturnal itching. Lice infest hair and clothing rather than burrowing into the skin.

 

Option B. Tick: Ticks are ectoparasites that attach to the skin and can transmit various diseases, such as Lyme disease. However, they do not cause the characteristic burrows or intense nocturnal itching seen in scabies.

 

Option D. Flea: Flea bites cause itchy red spots, primarily on the lower legs, but fleas do not burrow into the skin or cause the described distribution of burrows.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scabies is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis, which burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, particularly at night, and burrows in characteristic areas such as the axillae, umbilicus, and between the digits.

choices.text: Nipah virus

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category A agent? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthrax

 

Anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Category A agents are those deemed highest risk for use in bioterrorism due to their ease of dissemination or transmission and their high potential for significant public health impact, resulting in high mortality rates and the potential for major public health impact.

 

  • Characteristics of Anthrax:
    • Transmission: Can occur through cutaneous, inhalational, or gastrointestinal exposure to spore-forming bacteria.
    • Impact: Especially deadly in its inhalational form, anthrax can cause severe respiratory issues, shock, and often death if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah virus: It is not classified as a category A agent. It is a zoonotic virus that can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis, primarily in Southeast Asia.

 

Option C. Coxiella: The bacterium that causes Q fever, is not classified as a category A agent. Q fever is typically acquired from infected animals or their products.

 

Option D. Brucella: It causes brucellosis, zoonotic infection primarily transmitted through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

 

Other category A agents are:

 

  • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
  • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Smallpox (Variola virus)
  • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis) - Francisella tularensis bacteria cause tularemia, also known as rabbit fever.

choices.text: Fracture of the head of radius

questions.text: Nursemaid’s Elbow refers to which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Subluxation of proximal radioulnar joint

 

Nursemaid's Elbow refers to a subluxation of the proximal radioulnar joint where the annular ligament partially slips over the radial head. This typically occurs in young children (ages 1-4) when the arm is suddenly pulled longitudinally, such as when an adult pulls a child's hand to prevent falling or to lift them. The partial displacement of the annular ligament causes pain and the child typically holds the arm in pronation with the elbow slightly flexed, refusing to use it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This is incorrect. Nursemaid's Elbow is not a complete dislocation of the elbow joint but rather a subluxation specifically of the proximal radioulnar joint where the radius and ulna meet at the elbow.

 

Option B: This is incorrect. Subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint typically occurs from a fall on an outstretched hand and affects the wrist area, not the elbow. This is not Nursemaid's Elbow.

 

Option D: This is incorrect. Nursemaid's Elbow does not involve a fracture of the radial head. It is a soft tissue injury involving the annular ligament rather than a bony injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nursemaid's Elbow (radial head subluxation) is a common pediatric injury involving slippage of the annular ligament over the radial head at the proximal radioulnar joint, typically caused by longitudinal traction to the arm and treated with simple reduction maneuvers.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • ﻿﻿They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • ﻿﻿It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

 

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

 

In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

 

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.

 

Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection, characterized by eggs that are oval and thin-shelled, different from the barrel-shaped eggs of whipworm.

 

Option C. Necator americanus: Another species of hookworm with similar egg morphology to Ancylostoma duodenale.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: Causes ascariasis and is characterized by larger, oval, and thick-shelled eggs, distinct from the eggs of whipworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the distinctive egg morphology of Trichuris trichiura in stool samples is crucial for diagnosing whipworm infection. Proper sanitation and hygiene are key in preventing soil-transmitted helminth infections, and treatment involves specific antihelminthic medications to reduce the worm burden and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had arching of his back. What is the likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strychnine

 

STRYCHNINE NUX VOMICA

 

Active Principle: Strychnine, Brucine

 

Most Toxic part: Seeds (Fatal dose: 1 crushed seed; uncrushed seed not toxic)

 

MOA –

 

  • Competitive antagonist of glycine at post synaptic receptors
  • Strychnine inhibits the uptake of glycine, which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter at post-synaptic junction which gives excitatory effects
  • Spinal Cord: Anterior horn cells & brain stem also.

 

Clinical Presentation –

 

  • Very sudden onset
  • Dramatic presentation
  • “Conscious seizures”
    • Generalized
    • Simultaneous Convulsions (2-3 mins): All muscles affected at once
    • In b/w contractions muscles completely relaxed (5 mins)
      • Death occurs after 5-6 convulsions (1-2 hrs)

 

1. Opisthotonos: Hyper extension of spine

 

2. Emprosthotonus: Forward bending of spine (Sometimes)

 

3. Pleurosthotonus: Sideways bending of spine (Sometimes)

 

4. Risus Sardonicus: Contraction of facial muscles leading to smiling face

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ricinus communis (Castor) poisoning leads to burning pain in throat, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea and death.

 

Option C: Nerium odorum (cardiac poison) causes headache, dizziness, vomiting, low blood pressure, fibrillation, AV block, coma, and death can occur due to cardiac failure.

 

Option D: Datura poisoning show symptoms like

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strychnine poisoning presents with characteristic "conscious seizures" and back arching (opisthotonos) due to its antagonistic action on glycine receptors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female comes to the OPD with complaints of “feeling tensed” and having “stomach upset” symptoms, including heartburn and diarrhea. She states that she has been having these symptoms since she was 25 years old and that her family members are also usually tense and “nervous.” Which of the following symptoms are also likely to be present in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tingling of extremities

 

The patient presents with symptoms of anxiety, including constant feelings of tension, gastrointestinal symptoms like heartburn and diarrhea, and a family history of similar symptoms, suggesting a diagnosis of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD). GAD often includes somatic symptoms, such as tingling of the extremities, due to hyperventilation or heightened nervous system activity associated with anxiety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideas of Reference: This symptom is typically associated with psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia or delusional disorders, where the patient believes that events, objects, or other people have a special and personal significance. This is not characteristic of GAD.

 

Option C. Hallucinations: Hallucinations involve sensory perceptions without external stimuli and are common in psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia, but not in anxiety disorders.

 

Option D. Neologisms: Neologisms are newly coined words or phrases that have meaning only to the person using them and are commonly seen in formal thought disorders like schizophrenia. This is not a symptom seen in GAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) may experience somatic symptoms like tingling of extremities due to heightened anxiety and nervous system activity.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is characteristic of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitot spots

 

Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency. They appear as dry, foamy, triangular patches on the conjunctiva, typically on the temporal side of the cornea. These spots are part of a condition called xerophthalmia, which is dryness of the eye due to vitamin A deficiency. Bitot spots represent a more advanced stage of xerophthalmia, classified as stage X1B in the WHO classification of vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stocker's line: This is an iron deposition line seen in front of a pterygium. It is not related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Option B. Pinguecula: This is a yellowish, raised lesion on the conjunctiva near the corneal limbus. It's caused by elastotic degeneration due to prolonged UV exposure, not vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Option C. Pterygium: This is a wing-shaped growth of conjunctiva extending onto the cornea. Like pinguecula, it's associated with UV exposure and not vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency, appearing as dry, foamy patches on the conjunctiva and representing stage X1B of xerophthalmia.

questions.text: Siffert-Katz sign is seen in? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blount’s disease

 

Siffert-Katz sign refers to a palpable posteromedial depression of the proximal tibial metaphysis and epiphysis, which can be associated with varus instability of the knee in early flexion (around 15-20 degrees). This sign indicates an intra-articular deformity characteristic of Blount's disease. 

 

The abnormal growth at the medial tibial growth plate in Blount's disease leads to this characteristic bony depression. When the knee is flexed to around 15-20 degrees, this depression can become more prominent and may be associated with varus instability (a tendency for the knee to buckle inwards).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perthes Disease is a condition affecting the hip joint in children, typically between the ages of 4 and 10. It involves a temporary disruption of blood supply to the femoral head, causing it to lose bone mass and potentially deform. The pathological changes occur in the femoral head and acetabulum, leading to symptoms like limping, hip pain, and restricted hip movement. There is no involvement of the proximal tibia or the specific posteromedial depression seen in Blount's disease. 

 

Option C: Osteogenesis Imperfecta presents with multiple fractures at various stages of healing due to bone fragility. It has specific radiographic findings related to thin cortices and multiple fractures, not the Siffert-Katz sign.

 

Option D: Pulled elbow (Nursemaid's elbow) is a subluxation of the proximal radioulnar joint. It typically has normal radiographs as it's primarily a soft tissue injury involving the annular ligament.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Siffert-Katz sign, the palpable posteromedial depression of the proximal tibia associated with varus instability in early knee flexion, is a specific clinical finding that helps in the diagnosis of Blount's disease, particularly the infantile form. It reflects the unique way the proximal tibial growth plate is affected in this condition.

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol (398 mg/dl) & LDL (220 mg/dl) were found to be raised. Statins were given to this patient. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Familial hypercholesterolemia

 

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is a genetic disorder characterized by significantly elevated levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood. Tendon xanthomas are a common feature of FH. Statins are commonly prescribed to lower LDL cholesterol levels in FH patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoprotein lipase deficiency: Lipoprotein lipase deficiency is a different condition that affects the breakdown of triglycerides in lipoproteins, not cholesterol metabolism. It does not typically present with tendon xanthomas.

 

Option C. Tangier's disease: Tangier's disease is a rare genetic disorder that leads to very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. It does not typically present with elevated LDL cholesterol levels or tendon xanthomas.

 

Option D. Huntington's disease: Huntington's disease is a neurological disorder and is not related to cholesterol metabolism or tendon xanthomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All of the conditions i.e. tendon xanthomas, high serum cholesterol and LDL levels and statin therapy which is given to inhibit rate limiting enzyme HMG CoA reductase of cholesterol biosynthesis indicate that cholesterol is raised in this patient. So, the most probable diagnosis is Familial hypercholesterolemia aka Type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia that occur due to deficiency of LDL receptor on liver or Apo B100 mutation.

 

Lipoprotein lipase deficiency or Apo C- II defect cause familial hyperchylomicronemia or Type I hyperlipoproteinemia with raised plasma chylomicrons and TG levels.

 

In Tangier’s disease, there is defect in ABCA1 receptors causing low levels of plasma HDL.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 258

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with persistent weight loss, night sweats, and productive cough for the past two months. Which medium is most appropriate for isolating the causative organism? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium

 

The patient's presentation strongly suggests pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) based on:

 

  • Classic symptoms: persistent weight loss, night sweats, productive cough
  • Risk factor: diabetes mellitus (immunocompromised state)
  • Duration: symptoms lasting for two months (chronic course)

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative organism, requires special culture media because:

 

  • It does not grow on ordinary culture media
  • It is a slow-growing organism requiring enriched media
  • It needs specific nutrients and pH conditions for growth

 

Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is the gold standard for TB culture because:

 

  • It is an egg-based enriched medium containing glycerol and asparagine
  • Provides optimal nutrients for mycobacterial growth
  • Contains malachite green that inhibits other bacteria
  • Allows for characteristic colony formation (rough, buff-colored colonies)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loeffler serum slope (LSS):

 

  • Incorrect because:
  • Used primarily for Corynebacterium diphtheriae isolation

 

Option B. MacConkey agar:

 

  • Incorrect because:
  • Used for differentiating lactose-fermenting from non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacteria

 

Option C. Tinsdale medium:

 

  • Incorrect because:
  • Used specifically for Corynebacterium diphtheriae isolation as it allows the formation of characteristic black colonies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is the standard culture medium for isolating Mycobacterium tuberculosis from clinical specimens, as it provides the necessary enriched environment and selective conditions for optimal growth of this slow-growing organism.

 

 

CULTURE CHARACTERISTICS OF MYCOBACTERIUM TUBERCULOSIS

questions.text: After a road traffic accident case has been admitted, there is a blood spillage on the hospital floor. Which type of disinfectant would you select for cleaning the floor? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sodium hypochlorite

 

If there is spillage of blood on the hospital floor, sodium hypochlorite is the recommended disinfectant for cleaning the floor.

 

Procedure to be followed in the event of blood/body fluid spillage:

 

  1. Wear a pair of non-sterile gloves
  2. Broken glass (if any) of the container is cleaned first using tongs or a pan and brush and discarded in the sharp container. Caution is taken to not use hands.
  3. Disposable paper towels are used to absorb as much as possible.
  4. Water and detergent are used to clean the surface until visibly clean.
  5. The area is saturated with 0.5% Sodium Hypochlorite. This is prepared by diluting 5.25% sodium hypochlorite bleach at a 1:10 ratio.
  6. The tongs, pan, and brush are washed under running water and left to dry
  7. The gloves are removed and discarded.
  8. Hands are washed with soap and water using proper technique and dried with a disposable towel.
  9. The spillage is recorded in an incident book.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethyl alcohol: Is not recommended for cleaning surfaces with blood spills as it is less effective against some microorganisms and may evaporate too quickly.

 

Option B. Chlorhexidine: is also less effective against blood-borne pathogens and is better suited for skin disinfection.

 

Option D. Formaldehyde: Is not commonly used as a disinfectant due to its potential health hazards.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective disinfection of surfaces contaminated with blood spills, sodium hypochlorite is the preferred choice due to its broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity and ability to neutralize blood-borne pathogens.

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

 

The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression located on the lateral aspect of the wrist and the base of the thumb. When the thumb is extended, this depression becomes more pronounced. The lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box is formed by extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus. When you extend and abduct the thumb, you can typically feel these tendons, especially the abductor pollicis longus, become taut along the lateral border of the wrist, outlining the snuffbox.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. It extends the thumb's distal phalanx. The abductor pollicis brevis is a muscle of the thenar eminence and doesn't directly contribute to the boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox. Its tendon is not found in this region; instead, it inserts into the base of the thumb's proximal phalanx.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis: As already mentioned, the extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. The extensor pollicis brevis, in conjunction with the abductor pollicis longus, forms the lateral boundary. However, they don't together form just one boundary of the snuffbox.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis longus contributes to the lateral boundary of the snuffbox, as mentioned above. The abductor pollicis brevis, on the other hand, doesn't form any part of the snuffbox boundaries.

 

Educational Objective:
